Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multimodal Communication, mate choice and predation risk
Award.AbstractNarration: We receive and analyze information from our environment through multiple senses (i.e. sensory channels). When we interact socially, for example, we not only listen to someone?s words but we also read their body language to interpret their meaning. But how does information from different sensory channels interact to influence our social decisions? In this series of studies how acoustic and visual cues influence mate choice decisions will be determined in the túngara frog. As do most frogs, túngara frogs advertise for mates with loud and conspicuous mating calls. Females compare mating calls among males and use this information to choose a mate. But the female?s decision is also influenced by the presence of a visual cue, the male?s large and conspicuous vocal sac. Using robotic frogs it has been shown that females prefer a calling male with a large inflating-deflating vocal sac to a male producing the same call but without a dynamic vocal sac. To build upon those results to address several fundamental questions about how acoustic and visual cues interact to influence female decision making the following will be determined: What is the relative value of acoustic and visual cues? Does the addition of visual cues influence a female?s memory of calls? Do visual cues aid in recognizing individual males in large choruses? Does the addition of a visual cue influence the time it takes for females to make decisions? All of these studies will provide insights into how animals, including humans, integrate information in the environment around them through different sensory channels. In the process of this work, approximately 25 students, many of them women and minorities, will be trained in the use of robotic technologies to study behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: The research funded by this grant addresses multimodal communication in a frog. By multimodal we mean a communication system that involves stimuli that are perceived by different sensory modalities. This frog, the túngara frog, produces a loud and conspicuous mating call. Female frogs listen to the call when they are searching for a mate, and frog eating bats listen to the same call when they are searching for a meal. But there are other stimuli associated with the call. To produce the call the frog’s vocal sac must inflate and deflate, and this creates a very conspicuous visual cue that females see and the bats perceive with their echolocation. When the vocal sac inflates and deflates it also creates ripples on the surface of the water and both the female frogs in the frog eating bats can perceive these cues as well.

 We have made several important findings about multimodal communication in the research funded by this grant. (1) Attractive components of the call do not sum together in a predictable manner. For example, female frogs prefer calls of higher amplitude and greater complexity together with the presence of an inflating vocal sac. When these signal components are changed independently we find that there are complex nonlinearities between them. (2) Bats are able to echolocate the inflating vocal sac of the túngara frog and the bats are preferentially attracted to a call that is accompanied by this visual cue compared to a call alone. (3) Manipulation of the temporal association between acoustic and visual cues can disrupt perception of the courtship display by the female túngara frogs. This is quite similar to the McGurk effect in humans.  When humans perceive lip movements associated with one syllable and hear another syllable they then perceive a third syllable. (4) Unlike female túngara frogs, frog-eating bats are attracted to the chuck component of the whine-chuck call in the absence of whines. (5) Increased complexity of the sound environment increases the time it takes for the bats to fly to a call, but this time is decreased in the presence of the vocal-sac visual cue. (6) During the course of our studies we have also revealed a third modality in this communication system, seismic cues in the form of ripples on the water’s surface that results from the inflation and deflation of the vocal sac. These cues increase calling by neighbor males, are used by males in ranging their neighbors, and further aid bats in locating calling males.

 

Broader Impacts: We employed graduate students and interns from Latin America, including from Colombia, Costa Rica, Panama, and Peru, who were teamed with North American students, which promoted synergisms in training and in cultural exchanges. We also participated in STRI’s Amphibian Exhibit and Education Program in Punta Culebra, The Fabulous Frogs of Panama, to which we contributed both content and funds. The exhibit reaches approximately 100,000 visitors a year, including 35,000 schoolchildren (outreach documentation by STRI’s Director of Public Programs, Sharon Ryan). We have also contributed to the development of a classroom curriculum related to amphibians and STRI science in Spanish and English, which will be distributed to approximately 300 teachers in Panama and the United States, and which aligns with USA core curriculum standards and Panamanian national curriculum standards. We have developed two on-line phonotaxis experiments aimed at high-school aged students and this is located on the Taylor-Hunter Outreach website.  With this resource, students can conduct their own phonotaxis experiment through which they learn: 1) fundamentals of sexual selection and evolutionary biology, 2) fundamentals of animal behavior research, 3) hypothesis testing, and 4) statistical analysis. We also contributed to a travelling exhibit on amphibian conservation at the Smithsonian’s Natural History Museum in Washington DC. In addition, MJ Ryan wrote a popular science book for the general public that discussed many of the types of studies supported by the Division of IOS at NSF (A Taste for the Beautiful, Princeton University Press, February, 2018).
